title: 113_s342
content:
The Act titled "Pine Forest Range Recreation Enhancement Act of 2013" defines key terms like County, Map, Secretary, State, and Wilderness. It designates the Pine Forest Range Wilderness as an addition to the National Wilderness Preservation System. The Pine Forest Range Wilderness, encompassing approximately 26,000 acres of Federal land managed by the Bureau of Land Management, is designated as wilderness under the Wilderness Act. The boundary of the Wilderness bordered by a road shall be 100 feet from the edge of the road, with road adjustments required to reroute roads away from riparian areas. The Pine Forest Range Wilderness, covering 26,000 acres of Federal land managed by the Bureau of Land Management, is designated as wilderness under the Wilderness Act. The boundary of the Wilderness near roads shall be 100 feet from the road edge, with road adjustments needed to avoid riparian areas. The Wilderness boundary at Little Onion Reservoir shall be 160 feet downstream from the dam. The Secretary will create a map and legal description of the Wilderness with the same legal force as the Act, allowing for corrections of errors. The Pine Forest Range Wilderness, covering 26,000 acres of Federal land, is designated as wilderness under the Wilderness Act. The map and legal description will be available for public inspection. The Wilderness is withdrawn from various forms of entry, appropriation, and disposal under public land laws, as well as mining and mineral leasing laws. The administration of the Pine Forest Range Wilderness is outlined in Section 4. The Pine Forest Range Wilderness is administered by the Secretary in accordance with the Wilderness Act, with allowances for livestock grazing under certain regulations and guidelines. The Pine Forest Range Wilderness is administered according to specific guidelines and regulations. Any land acquired within the Wilderness boundary after the enactment of this Act will be included and managed as part of the Wilderness. Congress does not intend for the Wilderness designation to create a protective buffer zone, and nonwilderness activities visible or audible from the Wilderness are not prohibited. The Wilderness Act allows for military overflights, flight testing, and wildfire management within the Wilderness boundaries. The Secretary can take necessary measures for fire, insect, and disease control in coordination with state or local agencies. The Wilderness Act allows for wildfire management operations by Federal, State, or local agencies, including the installation of data collection devices for flood warning and water reservoir activities in the Wilderness. The land designated as wilderness by this Act is located in the semiarid region of the Great Basin, at the headwaters of streams and rivers with few water resource facilities or opportunities for water diversion outside the designated land. The purpose of this section is to protect the wilderness values of the designated land by means other than a federally reserved water right, as the land is generally unsuitable for new water resource facilities. Nothing in this Act constitutes a reservation of any water rights with respect to the Wilderness. The Secretary must adhere to Nevada water law to acquire and maintain any water rights for the Wilderness not existing before the Act's enactment. This does not establish a precedent for future wilderness designations or impact existing water rights. The Wilderness Act requires adherence to Nevada water law for acquiring and maintaining water rights. New projects are restricted, with a definition of water resource facilities provided. Wildlife guzzlers are excluded from this definition. Restriction on new water resource facilities within a wilderness area in the County, post-enactment of this Act, no funding, assistance, authorization, or permits allowed by the President or any US officer, employee, or agent. SEC. 5. RELEASE OF WILDERNESS STUDY AREAS.

Congress finds that the Blue Lakes and Alder Creek wilderness study areas have been adequately studied for wilderness designation. Any public land not designated as wilderness by this Act is no longer subject to certain regulations and shall be managed according to applicable land use plans.

SEC. 6. WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT. In accordance with the Wilderness Act, this Act does not affect the State's jurisdiction over fish and wildlife management in the Wilderness. The Secretary may conduct management activities to maintain or restore fish and wildlife populations, following wilderness management plans and relevant policies. The Secretary may conduct management activities to maintain or restore fish and wildlife populations in the Wilderness, following appropriate policies such as those in House Report 101-405. The Secretary may designate areas in the Wilderness where no hunting, fishing, or trapping is allowed for safety, administration, or legal compliance reasons. Consultation with the State agency and public notification is required before implementing such restrictions. The State can conduct wildlife management activities in the Wilderness according to a cooperative agreement with the Secretary, subject to applicable laws and regulations. The State can conduct wildlife management activities in the Wilderness through a cooperative agreement with the Secretary, where references to Clark County in the agreement are considered references to the Wilderness. SEC. 7. LAND EXCHANGES. In this section, the Secretary may exchange Federal land for non-Federal land, with the condition that the owner of the non-Federal land pays at least 50% of all related costs. Additional terms and conditions may also apply. The Secretary may require additional terms and conditions for land exchanges. Congress intends for exchanges to be completed within 5 years of the Act's enactment. SEC. 8. NATIVE AMERICAN CULTURAL AND RELIGIOUS USES. This Act does not affect the treaty rights of any Indian tribe.
